trans-unit.source: Build a Java web application using DocumentDB | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Build a Java web application using DocumentDB | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use the Azure DocumentDB service to store and access data from a Java application hosted on Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use the Azure DocumentDB service to store and access data from a Java application hosted on Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use the <linkText>Microsoft Azure DocumentDB</linkText><title></title> service to store and access data from a Java application hosted on Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use the <linkText>Microsoft Azure DocumentDB</linkText><title></title> service to store and access data from a Java application hosted on Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: In this topic, you will learn:
trans-unit.target: In this topic, you will learn:

trans-unit.source: How to build a basic JSP application in Eclipse.
trans-unit.target: How to build a basic JSP application in Eclipse.

trans-unit.source: How to work with the Azure DocumentDB service using the <linkText>DocumentDB Java SDK</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: How to work with the Azure DocumentDB service using the <linkText>DocumentDB Java SDK</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to create a web-based task-management application that enables you to create, retrieve, and mark tasks as complete, as shown in the following image.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to create a web-based task-management application that enables you to create, retrieve, and mark tasks as complete, as shown in the following image.

trans-unit.source: Each of the tasks in the ToDo list are stored as JSON documents in Azure DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: Each of the tasks in the ToDo list are stored as JSON documents in Azure DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>My ToDo List application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>My ToDo List application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you have prior experience using Java.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you have prior experience using Java.

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Java or the <linkText>prerequisite tools</linkText><title></title>, we recommend downloading the complete <linkText>todo</linkText><title></title> project from <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title> and building it using <linkText>the instructions at the end of this article</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Java or the <linkText>prerequisite tools</linkText><title></title>, we recommend downloading the complete <linkText>todo</linkText><title></title> project from <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title> and building it using <linkText>the instructions at the end of this article</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once you have it built, you can review the article to gain insight on the code in the context of the project.
trans-unit.target: Once you have it built, you can review the article to gain insight on the code in the context of the project.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Java Development Kit (JDK) 7+</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Java Development Kit (JDK) 7+</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers.</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers.</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>An Azure Website with a Java runtime environment (e.g. Tomcat or Jetty) enabled.</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>An Azure Website with a Java runtime environment (e.g. Tomcat or Jetty) enabled.</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: If you're installing these tools for the first time, coreservlets.com provides a walk-through of the installation process in the Quick Start section of their <linkText>Tutorial: Installing TomCat7 and Using it with Eclipse</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: If you're installing these tools for the first time, coreservlets.com provides a walk-through of the installation process in the Quick Start section of their <linkText>Tutorial: Installing TomCat7 and Using it with Eclipse</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: To provision a DocumentDB database account in Azure:
trans-unit.target: To provision a DocumentDB database account in Azure:

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have a database account, create one by following the instructions in <linkText>Create a database account</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have a database account, create one by following the instructions in <linkText>Create a database account</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you already have an account, proceed to step 2.
trans-unit.target: If you already have an account, proceed to step 2.

trans-unit.source: Using the Keys blade shown in the following illustration, copy your endpoint URI and the PRIMARY KEY to your clipboard and keep them handy as we will use these values in the web application we create next.
trans-unit.target: Using the Keys blade shown in the following illustration, copy your endpoint URI and the PRIMARY KEY to your clipboard and keep them handy as we will use these values in the web application we create next.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screen shot of the Azure Preview portal, showing a DocumentDB account, with the ACTIVE hub highlighted, the Keys button highlighted on the DocumentDB account blade, and the URI, PRIMARY KEY and SECONDARY KEY values highlighted on the Keys blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screen shot of the Azure Preview portal, showing a DocumentDB account, with the ACTIVE hub highlighted, the Keys button highlighted on the DocumentDB account blade, and the URI, PRIMARY KEY and SECONDARY KEY values highlighted on the Keys blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To create the JSP application:
trans-unit.target: To create the JSP application:

trans-unit.source: First, we’ll start off by creating a Java project.
trans-unit.target: First, we’ll start off by creating a Java project.

trans-unit.source: Start Eclipse, then click File, click New, and then click Dynamic Web Project.
trans-unit.target: Start Eclipse, then click File, click New, and then click Dynamic Web Project.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t see Dynamic Web Project listed as an available project, do the following: click File, click New, click Project…, expand Web, click Dynamic Web Project, and click Next.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t see Dynamic Web Project listed as an available project, do the following: click File, click New, click Project…, expand Web, click Dynamic Web Project, and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Enter a project name in the Project name box, and in the Target Runtime drop-down menu, optionally select a value (e.g. Apache Tomcat v7.0), and then click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Enter a project name in the Project name box, and in the Target Runtime drop-down menu, optionally select a value (e.g. Apache Tomcat v7.0), and then click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Selecting a target runtime enables you to run your project locally through Eclipse.
trans-unit.target: Selecting a target runtime enables you to run your project locally through Eclipse.

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse, in the Project Explorer view, expand your project.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse, in the Project Explorer view, expand your project.

trans-unit.source: Right-click WebContent, click New, and then click JSP File.
trans-unit.target: Right-click WebContent, click New, and then click JSP File.

trans-unit.source: In the New JSP File dialog box, name the file index.jsp.
trans-unit.target: In the New JSP File dialog box, name the file index.jsp.

trans-unit.source: Keep the parent folder as WebContent, as shown in the following illustration, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: Keep the parent folder as WebContent, as shown in the following illustration, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the Select JSP Template dialog box, for the purpose of this tutorial select New JSP File (html), and then click Finish.
trans-unit.target: In the Select JSP Template dialog box, for the purpose of this tutorial select New JSP File (html), and then click Finish.

trans-unit.source: When the index.jsp file opens in Eclipse, add text to display Hello World! within the existing element. Your updated content should look like the following code:
trans-unit.target: When the index.jsp file opens in Eclipse, add text to display Hello World! within the existing element. Your updated content should look like the following code:

trans-unit.source: Save the index.jsp file.
trans-unit.target: Save the index.jsp file.

trans-unit.source: If you set a target runtime in step 2, you can click Project and then Run to run your JSP application locally:
trans-unit.target: If you set a target runtime in step 2, you can click Project and then Run to run your JSP application locally:

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to pull in the DocumentDB Java SDK and its dependencies is through <linkText>Apache Maven</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to pull in the DocumentDB Java SDK and its dependencies is through <linkText>Apache Maven</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you will need to convert your project to a maven project by completing the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To do this, you will need to convert your project to a maven project by completing the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Right-click your project in the Project Explorer, click Configure, click Convert to Maven Project.
trans-unit.target: Right-click your project in the Project Explorer, click Configure, click Convert to Maven Project.

trans-unit.source: In the Create new POM window, accept the defaults and click Finish.
trans-unit.target: In the Create new POM window, accept the defaults and click Finish.

trans-unit.source: In Project Explorer, open the pom.xml file.
trans-unit.target: In Project Explorer, open the pom.xml file.

trans-unit.source: On the Dependencies tab, in the Dependencies pane, click Add.
trans-unit.target: On the Dependencies tab, in the Dependencies pane, click Add.

trans-unit.source: In the Select Dependency window, do the following:
trans-unit.target: In the Select Dependency window, do the following:

trans-unit.source: In the GroupId box, enter com.microsoft.azure.
trans-unit.target: In the GroupId box, enter com.microsoft.azure.

trans-unit.source: In the Artifact Id box enter azure-documentdb.
trans-unit.target: In the Artifact Id box enter azure-documentdb.

trans-unit.source: In the Version box enter 1.1.0.
trans-unit.target: In the Version box enter 1.1.0.

trans-unit.source: Or add the dependency XML for GroupId and ArtifactId directly to the pom.xml via a text editor:
trans-unit.target: Or add the dependency XML for GroupId and ArtifactId directly to the pom.xml via a text editor:

trans-unit.source: Click Ok and Maven will install the DocumentDB Java SDK.
trans-unit.target: Click Ok and Maven will install the DocumentDB Java SDK.

trans-unit.source: Save the pom.xml file.
trans-unit.target: Save the pom.xml file.

trans-unit.source: First, let's define the TodoItem object:
trans-unit.target: First, let's define the TodoItem object:

trans-unit.source: In this project, we are using <linkText>Project Lombok</linkText><title></title> to generate the constructor, getters, setters, and a builder.
trans-unit.target: In this project, we are using <linkText>Project Lombok</linkText><title></title> to generate the constructor, getters, setters, and a builder.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can write this code manually or have the IDE generate it.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can write this code manually or have the IDE generate it.

trans-unit.source: To invoke the DocumentDB service, you must instantiate a new DocumentClient.
trans-unit.target: To invoke the DocumentDB service, you must instantiate a new DocumentClient.

trans-unit.source: In general, it is best to reuse the DocumentClient - rather than construct a new client for each subsequent request.
trans-unit.target: In general, it is best to reuse the DocumentClient - rather than construct a new client for each subsequent request.

trans-unit.source: We can reuse the client by wrapping the client in a DocumentClientFactory.
trans-unit.target: We can reuse the client by wrapping the client in a DocumentClientFactory.

trans-unit.source: This is also where you need to paste the URI and PRIMARY KEY value you saved to your clipboard in <linkText>step 1</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This is also where you need to paste the URI and PRIMARY KEY value you saved to your clipboard in <linkText>step 1</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Replace [YOUR\ENDPOINT\HERE] with your URI and replace [YOUR\KEY\HERE] with your PRIMARY KEY.
trans-unit.target: Replace [YOUR\ENDPOINT\HERE] with your URI and replace [YOUR\KEY\HERE] with your PRIMARY KEY.

trans-unit.source: Now let's create a Data Access Object (DAO) to abstract persisting our ToDo items to DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: Now let's create a Data Access Object (DAO) to abstract persisting our ToDo items to DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: In order to save ToDo items to a collection, the client needs to know which database and collection to persist to (as referenced by self-links).
trans-unit.target: In order to save ToDo items to a collection, the client needs to know which database and collection to persist to (as referenced by self-links).

trans-unit.source: In general, it is best to cache the database and collection when possible to avoid additional round-trips to the database.
trans-unit.target: In general, it is best to cache the database and collection when possible to avoid additional round-trips to the database.

trans-unit.source: The following code illustrates how to retrieve our database and collection, if it exists, or create a new one if it doesn't exist:
trans-unit.target: The following code illustrates how to retrieve our database and collection, if it exists, or create a new one if it doesn't exist:

trans-unit.source: The next step is to write some code to persist the TodoItems in to the collection.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to write some code to persist the TodoItems in to the collection.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we will use <linkText>Gson</linkText><title></title> to serialize and de-serialize TodoItem Plain Old Java Objects (POJOs) to JSON documents.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we will use <linkText>Gson</linkText><title></title> to serialize and de-serialize TodoItem Plain Old Java Objects (POJOs) to JSON documents.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Jackson</linkText><title></title> or your own custom serializer are also great alternatives for serializing POJOs.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Jackson</linkText><title></title> or your own custom serializer are also great alternatives for serializing POJOs.

trans-unit.source: Like DocumentDB databases and collections, documents are also referenced by self-links.
trans-unit.target: Like DocumentDB databases and collections, documents are also referenced by self-links.

trans-unit.source: The following helper function lets us retrieve documents by another attribute (e.g. "id") rather than self-link:
trans-unit.target: The following helper function lets us retrieve documents by another attribute (e.g. "id") rather than self-link:

trans-unit.source: We can use the helper method in step 5 to retrieve a TodoItem JSON document by id and then deserialize it to a POJO:
trans-unit.target: We can use the helper method in step 5 to retrieve a TodoItem JSON document by id and then deserialize it to a POJO:

trans-unit.source: We can also use the DocumentClient to get a collection or list of TodoItems using DocumentDB SQL:
trans-unit.target: We can also use the DocumentClient to get a collection or list of TodoItems using DocumentDB SQL:

trans-unit.source: There are many ways to update a document with the DocumentClient.
trans-unit.target: There are many ways to update a document with the DocumentClient.

trans-unit.source: In our Todo list application, we want to be able to toggle whether a TodoItem is complete.
trans-unit.target: In our Todo list application, we want to be able to toggle whether a TodoItem is complete.

trans-unit.source: This can be achieved by updating the "complete" attribute within the document:
trans-unit.target: This can be achieved by updating the "complete" attribute within the document:

trans-unit.source: Finally, we want the ability to delete a TodoItem from our list.
trans-unit.target: Finally, we want the ability to delete a TodoItem from our list.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we can use the helper method we wrote earlier to retrieve the self-link and then tell the client to delete it:
trans-unit.target: To do this, we can use the helper method we wrote earlier to retrieve the self-link and then tell the client to delete it:

trans-unit.source: Now that we've finished the fun bits - all that left is to build a quick user interface and wire it up to our DAO.
trans-unit.target: Now that we've finished the fun bits - all that left is to build a quick user interface and wire it up to our DAO.

trans-unit.source: First, let's start with building a controller to call our DAO:
trans-unit.target: First, let's start with building a controller to call our DAO:

trans-unit.source: In a more complex application, the controller may house complicated business logic on top of the DAO.
trans-unit.target: In a more complex application, the controller may house complicated business logic on top of the DAO.

trans-unit.source: Next, we'll create a servlet to route HTTP requests to the controller:
trans-unit.target: Next, we'll create a servlet to route HTTP requests to the controller:

trans-unit.source: We'll need a Web User Interface to display to the user.
trans-unit.target: We'll need a Web User Interface to display to the user.

trans-unit.source: Let's re-write the index.jsp we created earlier:
trans-unit.target: Let's re-write the index.jsp we created earlier:

trans-unit.source: And finally, write some client-side Javascript to tie the web user interface and the servlet together:
trans-unit.target: And finally, write some client-side Javascript to tie the web user interface and the servlet together:

trans-unit.source: Awesome!
trans-unit.target: Awesome!

trans-unit.source: Now all that's left is to test the application.
trans-unit.target: Now all that's left is to test the application.

trans-unit.source: Run the application locally, and add some Todo items by filling in the item name and category and clicking Add Task.
trans-unit.target: Run the application locally, and add some Todo items by filling in the item name and category and clicking Add Task.

trans-unit.source: Once the item appears, you can update whether it's complete by toggling the checkbox and clicking Update Tasks.
trans-unit.target: Once the item appears, you can update whether it's complete by toggling the checkbox and clicking Update Tasks.

trans-unit.source: Azure Websites makes deploying Java Applications as simple as exporting your application as a WAR file and either uploading it via source control (e.g. GIT) or FTP.
trans-unit.target: Azure Websites makes deploying Java Applications as simple as exporting your application as a WAR file and either uploading it via source control (e.g. GIT) or FTP.

trans-unit.source: To export your application as a WAR, right-click on your project in Project Explorer, click Export, and then click WAR File.
trans-unit.target: To export your application as a WAR, right-click on your project in Project Explorer, click Export, and then click WAR File.

trans-unit.source: In the WAR Export window, do the following:
trans-unit.target: In the WAR Export window, do the following:

trans-unit.source: In the Web project box, enter azure-documentdb-java-sample.
trans-unit.target: In the Web project box, enter azure-documentdb-java-sample.

trans-unit.source: In the Destination box, choose a destination to save the WAR file.
trans-unit.target: In the Destination box, choose a destination to save the WAR file.

trans-unit.source: Click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have a WAR file in hand, you can simply upload it to your Azure Website's webapps directory.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have a WAR file in hand, you can simply upload it to your Azure Website's webapps directory.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on uploading the file, see <linkText>Adding an application to your Java website on Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on uploading the file, see <linkText>Adding an application to your Java website on Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once the WAR file is uploaded to the webapps directory, the runtime environment will detect that you've added it and will automatically load it.
trans-unit.target: Once the WAR file is uploaded to the webapps directory, the runtime environment will detect that you've added it and will automatically load it.

trans-unit.source: To view your finished product, navigate to http://YOUR\SITE\NAME.azurewebsites.net/azure-documentdb-java-sample/ and start adding your tasks!
trans-unit.target: To view your finished product, navigate to http://YOUR\SITE\NAME.azurewebsites.net/azure-documentdb-java-sample/ and start adding your tasks!

trans-unit.source: All the samples in this tutorial are included in the <linkText>todo</linkText><title></title> project on GitHub, which is part of the <linkText>azure-documentdb-java</linkText><title></title> repository.
trans-unit.target: All the samples in this tutorial are included in the <linkText>todo</linkText><title></title> project on GitHub, which is part of the <linkText>azure-documentdb-java</linkText><title></title> repository.

trans-unit.source: To import the todo project into Eclipse, ensure you have the software and resources listed in the <linkText>Prerequisites</linkText><title></title> section, then do the following:
trans-unit.target: To import the todo project into Eclipse, ensure you have the software and resources listed in the <linkText>Prerequisites</linkText><title></title> section, then do the following:

trans-unit.source: Install <linkText>Project Lombok</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Install <linkText>Project Lombok</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Lombok is used to generate constructors, getters, setters in the project.
trans-unit.target: Lombok is used to generate constructors, getters, setters in the project.

trans-unit.source: Once you have downloaded the lombok.jar file, double-click it to install it or install it from the command line.
trans-unit.target: Once you have downloaded the lombok.jar file, double-click it to install it or install it from the command line.

trans-unit.source: If Eclipse is open, close it and restart it to load Lombok.
trans-unit.target: If Eclipse is open, close it and restart it to load Lombok.

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse, on the File menu, click Import.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse, on the File menu, click Import.

trans-unit.source: In the Import window, click Git, click Projects from Git, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Import window, click Git, click Projects from Git, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select Repository Source screen, click Clone URI.
trans-unit.target: On the Select Repository Source screen, click Clone URI.

trans-unit.source: On the Source Git Repository screen, in the URI box, enter https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-java.git, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Source Git Repository screen, in the URI box, enter https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-java.git, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Branch Selection screen, ensure that master is selected, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Branch Selection screen, ensure that master is selected, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Local Destination screen, click Browse to select a folder where the repository can be copied, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Local Destination screen, click Browse to select a folder where the repository can be copied, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select a wizard to use for importing projects screen, ensure that Import existing projects is selected, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select a wizard to use for importing projects screen, ensure that Import existing projects is selected, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Import Projects screen, unselect the DocumentDB project, and then click Finish.
trans-unit.target: On the Import Projects screen, unselect the DocumentDB project, and then click Finish.

trans-unit.source: The DocumentDB project contains the DocumentDB Java SDK, which we will add as a dependency instead.
trans-unit.target: The DocumentDB project contains the DocumentDB Java SDK, which we will add as a dependency instead.

trans-unit.source: In Project Explorer, navigate to azure-documentdb-java-sample\src\com.microsoft.azure.documentdb.sample.dao\DocumentClientFactory.java and replace the HOST and MASTER_KEY values with the URI and PRIMARY KEY for your DocumentDB account, and then save the file.
trans-unit.target: In Project Explorer, navigate to azure-documentdb-java-sample\src\com.microsoft.azure.documentdb.sample.dao\DocumentClientFactory.java and replace the HOST and MASTER_KEY values with the URI and PRIMARY KEY for your DocumentDB account, and then save the file.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Step 1.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Step 1.

trans-unit.source: Create a DocumentDB database account](#CreateDB).
trans-unit.target: Create a DocumentDB database account](#CreateDB).

trans-unit.source: In Project Explorer, right click the azure-documentdb-java-sample, click Build Path, and then click Configure Build Path.
trans-unit.target: In Project Explorer, right click the azure-documentdb-java-sample, click Build Path, and then click Configure Build Path.

trans-unit.source: On the Java Build Path screen, in the right pane, select the Libraries tab, and then click Add External JARs.
trans-unit.target: On the Java Build Path screen, in the right pane, select the Libraries tab, and then click Add External JARs.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the location of the lombok.jar file, and click Open, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the location of the lombok.jar file, and click Open, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Use step 12 to open the Properties window again, and then in the left pane click Targeted Runtimes.
trans-unit.target: Use step 12 to open the Properties window again, and then in the left pane click Targeted Runtimes.

trans-unit.source: On the Targeted Runtimes screen, click New, select Apache Tomcat v7.0, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: On the Targeted Runtimes screen, click New, select Apache Tomcat v7.0, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Use step 12 to open the Properties window again, and then in the left pane click Project Facets.
trans-unit.target: Use step 12 to open the Properties window again, and then in the left pane click Project Facets.

trans-unit.source: On the Project Facets screen, select Dynamic Web Module and Java, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: On the Project Facets screen, select Dynamic Web Module and Java, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: On the Servers tab at the bottom of the screen, right-click Tomcat v7.0 Server at localhost and then click Add and Remove.
trans-unit.target: On the Servers tab at the bottom of the screen, right-click Tomcat v7.0 Server at localhost and then click Add and Remove.

trans-unit.source: On the Add and Remove window, move azure-documentdb-java-sample to the Configured box, and then click Finish.
trans-unit.target: On the Add and Remove window, move azure-documentdb-java-sample to the Configured box, and then click Finish.

trans-unit.source: In the Server tab, right-click Tomcat v7.0 Server at localhost, and then click Restart.
trans-unit.target: In the Server tab, right-click Tomcat v7.0 Server at localhost, and then click Restart.

trans-unit.source: In a browser, navigate to http://localhost:8080/azure-documentdb-java-sample/ and start adding to your task list.
trans-unit.target: In a browser, navigate to http://localhost:8080/azure-documentdb-java-sample/ and start adding to your task list.

trans-unit.source: Note that if you changed your default port values, change 8080 to the value you selected.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you changed your default port values, change 8080 to the value you selected.

trans-unit.source: To deploy your project to an Azure web site, see [Step 6.
trans-unit.target: To deploy your project to an Azure web site, see [Step 6.

trans-unit.source: Deploy your application to Azure Websites](#Deploy).
trans-unit.target: Deploy your application to Azure Websites](#Deploy).

trans-unit.source: media/documentdb-java-application/keys.png
trans-unit.target: media/documentdb-java-application/keys.png
